keywords.value: Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

byline.contributor: Liz Moyer contributed reporting from New York.

lead_paragraph: MetLife has been fighting since 2014 to remove the designation because of the extra regulatory scrutiny it brings.

headline.print_headline: MetLife Is Not ‘Too Big to Fail,’ Judge Rules, in Win for Insurer
headline.main: MetLife Wins Battle to Remove ‘Too Big to Fail’ Label

snippet: MetLife has been fighting since 2014 to remove the designation because of the extra regulatory scrutiny it brings.
abstract: Federal District Court Judge Rosemary M Collyer of District of Columbia removes 'too big to fail' designation from insurance giant MetLife; decision marks victory for company, but raises significant questions about how regulators will now classify other institutions under provision of Dodd-Frank Act.
